Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <CryptoAlex> @Crypto80 I bet DEX will be adopted when you can use them as a web app connect to a smartphone (like whatsapp). My hipotesis is that people are not used to download trading software on their PC and that they want to have the flexibility that web applications give them, but are really ok with downloading apps on their phones or needing them for access their trading web plataforms (2FA). As it seems, Q1/Q2 2019 seems to be the start of this trend, but maybe paying for listing has a short term benefit. Anyway, I belive the bullet points to discuss on the listing matter are:
1. When DEX model will gain traction?
2. How long the foundation can wait before starting selling their VRSC funds? 
3. How much money will be needed each month?
4. What is the expected impact in volume and price after the listing on the candidates exchanges?
5. How much will the listing cost on each exchange?
6. Is there any alternative for increasing the value and volume? 
7. Is there any alternative for listing instead of paying?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <ver_User> About the exchange  - I would think targeting one major exchange is the way to go, but I too do not know the costs. If we end up spread out over lots of little ones it will hinder price discovery as I think the Verus market would be too spread out and illiquid, and it would be an inefficient use of time/resources to get them set up.

Unless people really want to buy Verus, it's unlikely they will go and sign up to yet another (relatively unproven/untested/unknown) exchange when most traders already have to manage accounts for multiple exchanges already. People in general favour the easy route most of the time, especially nowadays with everything already done/predicted/saved for you online. I think being on digiprice is fine for now as we are so small and anyone who wants in will sign up. The same goes for many others IMO - you might get some of the existing userbase to take a look on different exchanges but to really get market participation you need to be where the market is, not expect it to come to you. Generally the market is still on bigger centralised exchanges. I wish it wasn't but...

I know nothing about how to get listed on an exchange but can't we aim for Binanance or similar? They list loads of coins. Binance CEO recently tipped Komodo as one to watch, I read in Komodo's 5 bullet Friday recently üòâ

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <ChrisC30a> Guys with multiple rigs / wallets...

Do you keep anything mined in separately wallets or combine them in to one?

If so, how?

Thanks

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <ok88> @ChrisC30a I spread everything across multiple transparent addresses to get better staking results

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <bigtom> @ok88 I heard that this does not matter.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <ok88> @bigtom How so? If an address strikes a stake block it's not staking again for X blocks, spreading into smaller UTXO will lower the downtime of coins in the staking process

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <bigtom> That is what I thought, but according to @miketout in #staking , this is not the case. Maybe there was some miscommunication there?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> @ok88 this is true, but once you get down to an amount that takes longer than a few thousand blocks to stake, the difference is minimal and offset by the time it can take to run through more transactions if you split them further. Right now, I am keeping my UTXOs 1000 or under, because it's convenient and I consider them small enough. I was originally recommending no larger than 500.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <ok88> Basically, we should keep em low (under 1000) and dispersed to stake effectively, having all in one wallet seems not right then. The optimum UTXO will increase with the growing supply and lower staking profits, but still having a single wallet is not the best way to stake.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> @brixporter The Z Cash privacy protocol is a bit different than most.  After you  mine coins and they are mature, you need to first send them to a Z Address that you create as a Receive address in your wallet.  Ie., you send them from your mining address to your Z Address (and you check the button that says ...
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/449638035999686677/479725180600713246/unknown.png

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> Then, after just one confirmation - you can send them from the Z Address -

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> @ok88 you can keep them all in one address even. How they are split makes no difference in probability of the total, aside from not being in UTXOs that are too large.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> @jimboscott actually, that is the Zcash protocol, which creates opt-out privacy. KMD has opt-in privacy and has removed the requirement. VRSC has the same requirement as Zcash.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> @miketout Thanks for the clarification....  I should have realized that it is a Z address for a reason and not a K address...

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <brixporter> I will try that @jimboscott , thanks a lot,!

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <brixporter> successüòÉ

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> @brixporter Cool.  Glad I could help...

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> If you want to STAKE VRSC, then after you send them to the Z Address you send them BACK to a regular transparent address.  After 150 confirmations they will then start taking.
